# Task

Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".



# Data

clean_column("My Column")

```julia
function clean_column(col)
    return lowercase(replace(strip(col), r"[-\s]+" => "_"))
end
```

To test:
```julia
clean_column("My Column") # returns "my_column"
clean_column(" My   Column ") # returns "my_column"
clean_column("My-Column") # returns "my_column"
clean_column("My  -  Column") # returns "my_column"
```

Here's how the `clean_column` function works:

1. `strip(col)` removes any leading or trailing whitespaces from the input string `col`.
2. `replace(strip(col), r"[-\s]+" => "_")` replaces any occurrences of one or more spaces or hyphens with an underscore `_` using a regular expression pattern `r"[-\s]+"`.
3. `lowercase(...)` converts the resulting string to lowercase.

The regular expression pattern `r"[-\s]+"` matches one or more occurrences of either a hyphen `-` or a whitespace character `\s` (space, tab, newline, etc.). The `replace` function replaces all matches of this pattern with an underscore `_`.
